title: Multi-focus - dog fur QDA scores 2 dotplots

content.question:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

Many veterinarians use the condition of a dog’s fur as an indicator of the dog’s overall health. A researcher is investigating the healthiness of the coats of fur for dogs from a certain population. The healthiness of a dog’s fur is evaluated using a quantitative description analysis <math alttext="(Q D A)" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, where a veterinarian uses a standard process to rate the fur from <math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, with higher values indicating healthier furs. From previous studies, the population distribution of the <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> scores for the fur of dogs is roughly uniform with mean <math alttext="mu equals 5.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5.4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and standard deviation <math alttext="sigma equals 2.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Describe the sampling distribution of the sample mean <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score, <math alttext="x bar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math>, for random samples of <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dogs from the population.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

Many veterinarians use the condition of a dog’s fur as an indicator of the dog’s overall health. A researcher is investigating the healthiness of the coats of fur for dogs from a certain population. The healthiness of a dog’s fur is evaluated using a quantitative description analysis <math alttext="(Q D A)" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, where a veterinarian uses a standard process to rate the fur from <math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, with higher values indicating healthier furs. From previous studies, the population distribution of the <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> scores for the fur of dogs is roughly uniform with mean <math alttext="mu equals 5.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5.4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and standard deviation <math alttext="sigma equals 2.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Describe the sampling distribution of the sample mean <math alttext="Q D A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score, <math alttext="x bar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math>, for random samples of <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dogs from the population.

(b) Calculate and interpret the value of <math alttext="the probability of, open parenthesis, x bar is greater than 5.9, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover><mo>></mo><mn>5.9</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the question.

The researcher conducted a study to investigate whether two supplements are different in promoting healthy coats of fur for dogs. The researcher randomly assigned <math alttext="70" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>70</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> dogs from a local animal shelter to receive one of the two supplements, with <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> receiving Supplement A and <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> receiving Supplement B. At the end of the study, a veterinarian, who was not aware of each dog’s assigned supplement, determined the <math alttext="Q D A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score for each dog.

The results of the study are shown in the following dotplots.

(c) Based on the dotplots, write a few sentences comparing the distributions of the <math alttext="Q D A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> scores for the dogs who received Supplement A and the dogs who received Supplement B.

The researcher will conduct a hypothesis test to investigate whether the sample data provide convincing statistical evidence that there is a difference between the two population means. Let <math alttext="mu sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the mean <math alttext="Q D A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score for all dogs similar to those in the study who could have been given Supplement A, and let <math alttext="mu sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the mean <math alttext="Q D A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> score for all dogs similar to those in the study who could have been given Supplement B. The hypotheses for the test are as follows.

<math alttext="H sub 0: mu sub A, equals mu sub B. H sub a: mu sub A, is not equal to mu sub B" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtable columnalign="left" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtext>H</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>≠</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></math>

(d) After examining the two dotplots, the researcher is concerned that a condition for the test may not be satisfied. Explain why the researcher should not be concerned.

A <math alttext="93%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>93</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> confidence interval for a difference between the population means (Supplement A minus Supplement B) is <math alttext="3.143 plus or minus 1.170" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.143</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>1.170</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(e) Based on the confidence interval, what conclusion should the researcher make for the hypothesis test? Justify your answer.

(f) Based on the conclusion from part (e), describe, in the context of the study, the type of error (Type <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> or Type <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) the researcher might have made, and also describe a consequence of making this type of error.

topic.text: 1.9: Comparing Distributions of a Quantitative Variable

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Compare distributions or relative positions of points within a distribution.
